dn22:0.2.eng: The Longer Discourse on Mindfulness Meditation

dn22:1.1.comm: This discourse is copied from MN 10. The section on the four noble truths has been expanded with material mostly drawn from MN 141. These discourses are the most influential texts for modern Theravada meditation, prompting countless modern commentaries. Comparative study of the several parallel versions reveals that this discourse, while comprised almost entirely of early material, was compiled in this form as one of the latest texts in the Pali suttas. | While mindfulness is always useful (SN 46.53:15.4), the “establishment of mindfulness” (satipaṭṭhāna) refers especially to a conscious development of contemplative practices based on mindfulness, i.e. “mindfulness meditation”.

dn22:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kurūsu viharati kammāsadhammaṃ nāma kurūnaṃ nigamo.
dn22:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kurus, near the Kuru town named Kammāsadamma.

dn22:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

dn22:1.7.pli: “Ekāyano ayaṃ, bhikkhave, maggo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā, sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya, yadidaṃ cattāro satipaṭṭhānā.
dn22:1.7.eng: “Mendicants, the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.
dn22:1.7.comm: The phrase ekāyano maggo (“path to convergence”) is given multiple meanings in commentaries and ancient translations. Outside of satipaṭṭhāna, it is used in only one context in Pali, where it means to “come together with” (MN 12:37.5). At SN 47.18:3.4 the phrase is spoken by Brahmā, which suggests it was a Brahmanical term. At Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.11—a passage full of details shared with the suttas—it means a place where things unite or converge. Thus satipaṭṭhāna leads to everything “coming together as one”. In other words, as seventh factor of the noble eightfold path, it leads to samādhi, the eighth factor (SN 45.1:3.9; see also MN 44:12.3).

dn22:1.9.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ,
dn22:1.9.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
dn22:1.9.comm: The idiom kāye kāyānupassī, literally “observes a body in the body” refers to focusing on a specific aspect of embodied experience, such as the breath, the postures, etc. | “Keen” (or “ardent”, ātāpī) implies effort, while “aware” (sampajāno) is the wisdom of understanding situation and context. | “Covetousness and displeasure” (abhijjhādomanassaṁ) are the strong forms of desire and aversion that are overcome by sense restraint in preparation for meditation.

dn22:1.10.pli: vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ,
dn22:1.10.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
dn22:1.10.comm: “Feelings” (vedanā) are the basic tones of pleasant, painful, or neutral, not the complexes we call “emotions”.

dn22:1.11.pli: citte cittānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ,
dn22:1.11.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
dn22:1.11.comm: “Mind” (citta) is simple awareness. In meditation contexts, “mind” is often similar in meaning to samādhi.

dn22:1.12.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
dn22:1.12.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
dn22:1.12.comm: “Principles” (dhammā) are the natural “systems” of cause and effect that underlie the “teachings”. The renderings “mind objects” or “mental qualities” are incorrect, as many of the things spoken of in this section are neither mind objects nor mental qualities. “Phenomena” is a possible translation, but the emphasis is not on the “appearance” of things, but on the “principles” governing their conditional relations.

dn22:2.1.pli: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati?
dn22:2.1.eng: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of the body?

dn22:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
dn22:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down cross-legged, sets their body straight, and establishes mindfulness in their presence.
dn22:2.2.comm: The context here—a mendicant gone to the forest—establishes that this practice takes place in the wider context of the Gradual Training. Indeed, this whole sutta can be understood as an expansion of this phrase, mentioned briefly at DN 2:67.3.

dn22:2.3.eng: Just mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out.
dn22:2.3.comm: The most fundamental meditation instruction in Buddhism. Notice how the Buddha phrases it: not “concentrate on the breath” as an object, but rather “breathing” as an activity to which one brings mindfulness.

dn22:2.4.pli: Dīghaṃ vā assasanto ‘dīghaṃ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, dīghaṃ vā passasanto ‘dīghaṃ passasāmī’ti pajānāti.
dn22:2.4.eng: Breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ Breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’
dn22:2.4.comm: The stages of breath meditation are not meant to be done deliberately, but to be observed and understood as the natural process of deepening meditation. When starting out, the breath is somewhat rough and coarse.

dn22:2.5.pli: Rassaṃ vā assasanto ‘rassaṃ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, rassaṃ vā passasanto ‘rassaṃ passasāmī’ti pajānāti.
dn22:2.5.eng: When breathing in lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing in lightly.’ Breathing out lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing out lightly.’
dn22:2.5.comm: Over time, the breath becomes more subtle and soft.

dn22:2.6.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the whole body.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the whole body.’
dn22:2.6.comm: Contextually the idiom “whole body” (sabbakāya) here refers to the breath, marking the fuller and more continuous awareness that arises with tranquility. Some practitioners, however, interpret it as the “whole physical body”, broadening awareness to encompass the movement and settling of energies throughout the body.

dn22:2.7.pli: ‘Passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati.
dn22:2.7.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the physical process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the physical process.’
dn22:2.7.comm: The “physical process” (kāyasaṅkhāraṁ) is the breath (SN 41.6:1.8).

dn22:2.8.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dakkho bhamakāro vā bhamakārantevāsī vā dīghaṃ vā añchanto ‘dīghaṃ añchāmī’ti pajānāti, rassaṃ vā añchanto ‘rassaṃ añchāmī’ti pajānāti;
dn22:2.8.eng: It’s like a deft carpenter or carpenter’s apprentice. When making a deep cut they know: ‘I’m making a deep cut,’ and when making a shallow cut they know: ‘I’m making a shallow cut.’
dn22:2.8.comm: Text has “long” and “short”, but “deep” and “shallow” or “heavy” and “light” are more idiomatic for describing the breath in English.

dn22:2.9.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dīghaṃ vā assasanto ‘dīghaṃ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, dīghaṃ vā passasanto ‘dīghaṃ passasāmī’ti pajānāti, rassaṃ vā assasanto ‘rassaṃ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, rassaṃ vā passasanto ‘rassaṃ passasāmī’ti pajānāti.

dn22:2.10.pli: ‘Sabbakāyapaṭisaṃvedī assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘sabbakāyapaṭisaṃvedī passasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati.

dn22:2.11.pli: Iti ajjhattaṃ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
dn22:2.11.eng: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally, externally, and both internally and externally.
dn22:2.11.comm: “Internally” is one’s own body, “externally” the bodies of others, or external physical phenomena. This distinction is applied broadly in Buddhist meditation, but it is more relevant in some contexts than others. In the case of the breath, one is focusing on one’s own breath, but when contemplating, say, a dead body, or the material elements, there is more of an external dimension. Starting with “me” in here and the “world” out there, this practice dissolves this distinction so that we see we are of the same nature as everything else.

dn22:2.12.pli: Samudayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṃ viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṃ viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṃ viharati.
dn22:2.12.eng: They meditate observing the body as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to both originate and vanish.
dn22:2.12.comm: This is the vipassanā (“insight” or “discernment”) dimension of meditation, observing not just the rise and fall of phenomena, but also their conditioned “nature” as being “liable” (-dhamma) to impermanence. The meaning of this passage is explained at (SN 47.42). Apart from these passages, vipassanā in satipaṭṭhāna pertains specially to the observation of principles.

dn22:2.13.pli: ‘Atthi kāyo’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
dn22:2.13.eng: Or mindfulness is established that the body exists, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.
dn22:2.13.comm: Mindfulness meditation leads to a range of knowledges as detailed by Anuruddha at SN 52.6 and SN 52.11–24. An arahant is “independent” of any attachment (eg. MN 143), but satipaṭṭhāna is also taught to give up dependency on views of the past and future (DN 29:40.1).

dn22:2.14.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
dn22:2.14.eng: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

dn22:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gacchanto vā ‘gacchāmī’ti pajānāti, ṭhito vā ‘ṭhitomhī’ti pajānāti, nisinno vā ‘nisinnomhī’ti pajānāti, sayāno vā ‘sayānomhī’ti pajānāti,
dn22:3.1.eng: Furthermore, when a mendicant is walking they know: ‘I am walking.’ When standing they know: ‘I am standing.’ When sitting they know: ‘I am sitting.’ And when lying down they know: ‘I am lying down.’
dn22:3.1.comm: In early Pali, this practice is found only in the two Satipaṭṭhānasuttas and the closely related Kāyagatāsatisutta (MN 119). It is practiced by developing a reflexive awareness of one’s posture and activity as it proceeds, often assisted by moving slowly and carefully.

dn22:3.2.pli: yathā yathā vā panassa kāyo paṇihito hoti tathā tathā naṃ pajānāti.
dn22:3.2.eng: Whatever posture their body is in, they know it.

dn22:3.3.pli: Iti ajjhattaṃ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
dn22:3.3.eng: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

dn22:3.4.pli: Samudayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṃ viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṃ viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṃ viharati.
dn22:3.4.eng: They meditate observing the body as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to both originate and vanish.

dn22:3.5.pli: ‘Atthi kāyo’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
dn22:3.5.eng: Or mindfulness is established that the body exists, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

dn22:3.6.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
dn22:3.6.eng: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

dn22:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
dn22:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl, and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
dn22:4.1.comm: “Situational awareness” (sampajañña) understands the context and purpose of activities. The main examples here illustrate the activities of daily monastic life: leaving the monastery on almsround, restraint while in the town, care wearing the robes, then mindfully eating and going to the toilet.

dn22:4.2.eng: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally …

dn22:4.3.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
dn22:4.3.eng: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

dn22:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ uddhaṃ pādatalā adho kesamatthakā tacapariyantaṃ pūraṃ nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati:
dn22:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant examines their own body, up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth.
dn22:5.1.comm: This practice is intended to counter sexual desire and obsession. The primary focus is on one’s own body, rather than another’s body, although that can be brought in also. By focusing on aspects of our body that we normally prefer to ignore, we move towards a healthy sense of acceptance and neutrality towards our body.

dn22:5.2.pli: ‘atthi imasmiṃ kāye kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco, maṃsaṃ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṃ vakkaṃ, hadayaṃ yakanaṃ kilomakaṃ pihakaṃ papphāsaṃ, antaṃ antaguṇaṃ udariyaṃ karīsaṃ, pittaṃ semhaṃ pubbo lohitaṃ sedo medo, assu vasā kheḷo siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttan’ti.
dn22:5.2.eng: ‘In this body there is head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine.’
dn22:5.2.comm: Thirty-one parts are mentioned in early texts, later expanded to thirty-two with the addition of the “brain” (matthaluṅga).

dn22:5.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ubhatomukhā putoḷi pūrā nānāvihitassa dhaññassa, seyyathidaṃ—sālīnaṃ vīhīnaṃ muggānaṃ māsānaṃ tilānaṃ taṇḍulānaṃ. Tamenaṃ cakkhumā puriso muñcitvā paccavekkheyya: ‘ime sālī, ime vīhī ime muggā ime māsā ime tilā ime taṇḍulā’ti.
dn22:5.3.eng: It’s as if there were a bag with openings at both ends, filled with various kinds of grains, such as fine rice, wheat, mung beans, peas, sesame, and ordinary rice. And a person with clear eyes were to open it and examine the contents: ‘These grains are fine rice, these are wheat, these are mung beans, these are peas, these are sesame, and these are ordinary rice.’
dn22:5.3.comm: The “bag with openings at both ends” is the body. Not all the varieties of grains and beans can be positively identified.

dn22:5.4.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ uddhaṃ pādatalā adho kesamatthakā tacapariyantaṃ pūraṃ nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati:

dn22:5.6.eng: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally …

dn22:5.7.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
dn22:5.7.eng: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

dn22:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ yathāṭhitaṃ yathāpaṇihitaṃ dhātuso paccavekkhati:
dn22:6.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant examines their own body, whatever its placement or posture, according to the elements:
dn22:6.1.comm: While meditation on the elements is commonly taught in early texts, this phrase is found only in the two Satipaṭṭhānasuttas and the Kāyagatāsatisutta. Detailed instructions are found in such suttas as MN 28 and MN 140. This meditation works in any posture, whereas breath meditation is best done sitting, to allow the breath to become still.

dn22:6.2.pli: ‘atthi imasmiṃ kāye pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti.
dn22:6.2.eng: ‘In this body there is the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.’
dn22:6.2.comm: The “elements” are the four states of matter as represented by their primary material example and their dominant property: earth as a solid with the property of resisting or upholding; water as a liquid with the property of binding; air as a gas with the property of movement; and fire (“heat” or “energy”) as plasma with the property of transformation.

dn22:6.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dakkho goghātako vā goghātakantevāsī vā gāviṃ vadhitvā catumahāpathe bilaso vibhajitvā nisinno assa;
dn22:6.3.eng: It’s as if a deft butcher or butcher’s apprentice were to kill a cow and sit down at the crossroads with the meat cut into chops.
dn22:6.3.comm: This gruesome image shows that butchery of cows was a normal feature of ancient Indian life.

dn22:6.4.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ yathāṭhitaṃ yathāpaṇihitaṃ dhātuso paccavekkhati:

dn22:6.5.pli: ‘atthi imasmiṃ kāye pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti.

dn22:6.6.pli: Iti ajjhattaṃ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati …pe…
dn22:6.6.eng: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally …

dn22:6.7.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
dn22:6.7.eng: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

dn22:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṃ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṃ ekāhamataṃ vā dvīhamataṃ vā tīhamataṃ vā uddhumātakaṃ vinīlakaṃ vipubbakajātaṃ.
dn22:7.1.eng: Furthermore, suppose a mendicant were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And it had been dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering.
dn22:7.1.comm: Cremation was expensive and not available to everyone. Bodies might be left in the charnel ground for a variety of reasons, such as local customs, lack of funds, or in cases of inauspicious death such as murder or execution. This is still seen in some places today, and monastics occasionally take the opportunity to practice meditation beside a corpse. However the wording of the Pali sounds like an imaginative exercise.

dn22:7.2.eng: They’d compare it with their own body:
dn22:7.2.comm: The observed corpse is not gendered. The purpose is not to become repulsed by an objectified other, but to understand the mortality of one’s own body.

dn22:7.3.eng: ‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’

dn22:7.4.eng: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally …

dn22:7.5.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
dn22:7.5.eng: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

dn22:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṃ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṃ kākehi vā khajjamānaṃ kulalehi vā khajjamānaṃ gijjhehi vā khajjamānaṃ kaṅkehi vā khajjamānaṃ sunakhehi vā khajjamānaṃ byagghehi vā khajjamānaṃ dīpīhi vā khajjamānaṃ siṅgālehi vā khajjamānaṃ vividhehi vā pāṇakajātehi khajjamānaṃ.
dn22:8.1.eng: Furthermore, suppose they were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground being devoured by crows, hawks, vultures, herons, hounds, tigers, leopards, jackals, and many kinds of little creatures.

dn22:8.2.eng: They’d compare it with their own body:

dn22:8.3.eng: ‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’

dn22:8.4.eng: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally …

dn22:8.5.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
dn22:8.5.eng: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

dn22:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṃ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṃ aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikaṃ samaṃsalohitaṃ nhārusambandhaṃ …pe…
dn22:9.1.eng: Furthermore, suppose they were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground, a skeleton with flesh and blood, held together by sinews …

dn22:9.2.eng: A skeleton without flesh but smeared with blood, and held together by sinews …

dn22:9.3.eng: A skeleton rid of flesh and blood, held together by sinews …

dn22:9.4.pli: Aṭṭhikāni apagatasambandhāni disā vidisā vikkhittāni, aññena hatthaṭṭhikaṃ aññena pādaṭṭhikaṃ aññena gopphakaṭṭhikaṃ aññena jaṅghaṭṭhikaṃ aññena ūruṭṭhikaṃ aññena kaṭiṭṭhikaṃ aññena phāsukaṭṭhikaṃ aññena piṭṭhiṭṭhikaṃ aññena khandhaṭṭhikaṃ aññena gīvaṭṭhikaṃ aññena hanukaṭṭhikaṃ aññena dantaṭṭhikaṃ aññena sīsakaṭāhaṃ.
dn22:9.4.eng: Bones rid of sinews, scattered in every direction. Here a hand-bone, there a foot-bone, here an ankle bone, there a shin-bone, here a thigh-bone, there a hip-bone, here a rib-bone, there a back-bone, here an arm-bone, there a neck-bone, here a jaw-bone, there a tooth, here the skull. …

dn22:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṃ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṃ aṭṭhikāni setāni saṅkhavaṇṇapaṭibhāgāni …pe…
dn22:10.1.eng: White bones, the color of shells …

dn22:10.2.eng: Decrepit bones, heaped in a pile …

dn22:10.3.eng: Bones rotted and crumbled to powder.
dn22:10.3.comm: It takes decades for bones to rot to powder, again suggesting it is an imaginative contemplation.

dn22:10.4.eng: They’d compare it with their own body:

dn22:10.5.eng: ‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’

dn22:10.6.pli: Iti ajjhattaṃ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
dn22:10.6.eng: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

dn22:10.7.pli: Samudayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṃ viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṃ viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṃ viharati.
dn22:10.7.eng: They meditate observing the body as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to both originate and vanish.

dn22:10.8.pli: ‘Atthi kāyo’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
dn22:10.8.eng: Or mindfulness is established that the body exists, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

dn22:10.9.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
dn22:10.9.eng: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

dn22:11.1.pli: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati?
dn22:11.1.eng: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of feelings?
dn22:11.1.comm: Literally “a feeling among the feelings”; the practice shows that the meditator contemplates specific feelings as they occur.

dn22:11.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhaṃ vā vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
dn22:11.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant who feels a pleasant feeling knows: ‘I feel a pleasant feeling.’
dn22:11.2.comm: Pali employs direct quotes to indicate reflexive awareness: you feel the feeling and you know that you feel the feeling. It does not mean that you have to literally say “I feel a pleasant feeling”, although some adopt that as a meditation method.

dn22:11.3.pli: Dukkhaṃ vā vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
dn22:11.3.eng: When they feel a painful feeling, they know: ‘I feel a painful feeling.’

dn22:11.4.pli: Adukkhamasukhaṃ vā vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
dn22:11.4.eng: When they feel a neutral feeling, they know: ‘I feel a neutral feeling.’

dn22:11.5.pli: Sāmisaṃ vā sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘sāmisaṃ sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
dn22:11.5.eng: When they feel a pleasant feeling of the flesh, they know: ‘I feel a pleasant feeling of the flesh.’
dn22:11.5.comm: Feelings “of the flesh” (sāmisa) are associated with the body and sensual desires (SN 36.31:4.1).

dn22:11.6.pli: Nirāmisaṃ vā sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘nirāmisaṃ sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
dn22:11.6.eng: When they feel a pleasant feeling not of the flesh, they know: ‘I feel a pleasant feeling not of the flesh.’
dn22:11.6.comm: Feelings “not of the flesh” (nirāmisa) are associated with renunciation and especially with the jhānas and liberation (SN 36.31:5.1).

dn22:11.7.pli: Sāmisaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘sāmisaṃ dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
dn22:11.7.eng: When they feel a painful feeling of the flesh, they know: ‘I feel a painful feeling of the flesh.’

dn22:11.8.pli: Nirāmisaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘nirāmisaṃ dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
dn22:11.8.eng: When they feel a painful feeling not of the flesh, they know: ‘I feel a painful feeling not of the flesh.’
dn22:11.8.comm: This would include the feelings of loss, doubt, and dejection that can occur during the spiritual path (see MN 44:28.6).

dn22:11.9.pli: Sāmisaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘sāmisaṃ adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
dn22:11.9.eng: When they feel a neutral feeling of the flesh, they know: ‘I feel a neutral feeling of the flesh.’

dn22:11.10.pli: Nirāmisaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘nirāmisaṃ adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
dn22:11.10.eng: When they feel a neutral feeling not of the flesh, they know: ‘I feel a neutral feeling not of the flesh.’
dn22:11.10.comm: The feeling of the fourth jhāna and higher liberations (SN 36.31:8.2).

dn22:11.11.pli: Iti ajjhattaṃ vā vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati.
dn22:11.11.eng: And so they meditate observing an aspect of feelings internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

dn22:11.12.pli: Samudayadhammānupassī vā vedanāsu viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā vedanāsu viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā vedanāsu viharati.
dn22:11.12.eng: They meditate observing feelings as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to both originate and vanish.

dn22:11.13.pli: ‘Atthi vedanā’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
dn22:11.13.eng: Or mindfulness is established that feelings exist, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

dn22:11.14.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati.
dn22:11.14.eng: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of feelings.

dn22:12.1.pli: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu citte cittānupassī viharati?
dn22:12.1.eng: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of the mind?

dn22:12.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘sarāgaṃ cittan’ti pajānāti.
dn22:12.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant understands mind with greed as ‘mind with greed,’
dn22:12.2.comm: In Buddhist theory, awareness of the presence or absence of qualities such as greed is explained on three levels. There is the simple happenstance of whether greed is present at that time or not. Then there is the mind freed of greed through the power of absorption. Finally there is the liberation from greed which comes with full awakening.

dn22:12.3.eng: and mind without greed as ‘mind without greed.’

dn22:12.4.eng: They understand mind with hate as ‘mind with hate,’

dn22:12.5.eng: and mind without hate as ‘mind without hate.’

dn22:12.6.eng: They understand mind with delusion as ‘mind with delusion,’

dn22:12.7.eng: and mind without delusion as ‘mind without delusion.’

dn22:12.8.eng: They know constricted mind as ‘constricted mind,’
dn22:12.8.comm: The mind is “constricted internally” due to dullness and “scattered externally” due to the distractions of desire (SN 51.20:18.1).

dn22:12.10.eng: They know expansive mind as ‘expansive mind,’
dn22:12.10.comm: The following terms “expansive” (mahaggata), “supreme” (anuttara), “immersed” (samāhita), and “freed” (vimutta) all refer to states of absorption and/or awakening.

dn22:12.12.eng: They know mind that is not supreme as ‘mind that is not supreme,’

dn22:12.13.eng: and mind that is supreme as ‘mind that is supreme.’

dn22:12.14.eng: They know mind immersed in samādhi as ‘mind immersed in samādhi,’

dn22:12.15.eng: and mind not immersed in samādhi as ‘mind not immersed in samādhi.’

dn22:12.16.eng: They know freed mind as ‘freed mind,’

dn22:12.18.pli: Iti ajjhattaṃ vā citte cittānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā citte cittānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā citte cittānupassī viharati.
dn22:12.18.eng: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the mind internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

dn22:12.19.pli: Samudayadhammānupassī vā cittasmiṃ viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā cittasmiṃ viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā cittasmiṃ viharati.
dn22:12.19.eng: They meditate observing the mind as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to both originate and vanish.

dn22:12.20.pli: ‘Atthi cittan’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
dn22:12.20.eng: Or mindfulness is established that the mind exists, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

dn22:12.21.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu citte cittānupassī viharati.
dn22:12.21.eng: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the mind.

dn22:13.1.pli: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati?
dn22:13.1.eng: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles?

dn22:13.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu nīvaraṇesu.
dn22:13.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five hindrances.
dn22:13.2.comm: The Satipaṭṭhānavibhaṅga of the Pali Abhidhamma only mentions the hindrances and awakening factors in this section (Vb 7). This, together with a range of other evidence, suggests that this was the original content of the observation of principles.

dn22:13.3.pli: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu nīvaraṇesu?
dn22:13.3.eng: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five hindrances?

dn22:13.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ kāmacchandaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ kāmacchando’ti pajānāti, asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ kāmacchandaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ kāmacchando’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa kāmacchandassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa kāmacchandassa pahānaṃ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa kāmacchandassa āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
dn22:13.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant who has sensual desire in them understands: ‘I have sensual desire in me.’ When they don’t have sensual desire in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have sensual desire in me.’ They understand how sensual desire arises; how, when it’s already arisen, it’s given up; and how, once it’s given up, it doesn’t arise again in the future.
dn22:13.4.comm: Here causality is introduced. In the contemplation of mind, the meditator was aware of the presence or absence of desire in the mind. Now they look deeper, investigating the cause of desire and understanding how to be free of it forever. This contemplation of the “principles” of cause and effect is the distinctive feature of this section.

dn22:13.5.pli: Santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ byāpādaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ byāpādo’ti pajānāti, asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ byāpādaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ byāpādo’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa byāpādassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa byāpādassa pahānaṃ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa byāpādassa āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
dn22:13.5.eng: When they have ill will in them, they understand: ‘I have ill will in me.’ When they don’t have ill will in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have ill will in me.’ They understand how ill will arises; how, when it’s already arisen, it’s given up; and how, once it’s given up, it doesn’t arise again in the future.

dn22:13.6.pli: Santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ thinamiddhaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ thinamiddhan’ti pajānāti, asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ thinamiddhaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ thinamiddhan’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa thinamiddhassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa thinamiddhassa pahānaṃ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa thinamiddhassa āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
dn22:13.6.eng: When they have dullness and drowsiness in them, they understand: ‘I have dullness and drowsiness in me.’ When they don’t have dullness and drowsiness in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have dullness and drowsiness in me.’ They understand how dullness and drowsiness arise; how, when they’ve already arisen, they’re given up; and how, once they’re given up, they don’t arise again in the future.
dn22:13.6.comm: The Buddhist schools debated whether this included physical tiredness or not. The Theravada argued that it was purely a mental laziness, as even the Buddha got sleepy.

dn22:13.7.pli: Santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ uddhaccakukkuccaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ uddhaccakukkuccan’ti pajānāti, asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ uddhaccakukkuccaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ uddhaccakukkuccan’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa uddhaccakukkuccassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa uddhaccakukkuccassa pahānaṃ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa uddhaccakukkuccassa āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
dn22:13.7.eng: When they have restlessness and remorse in them, they understand: ‘I have restlessness and remorse in me.’ When they don’t have restlessness and remorse in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have restlessness and remorse in me.’ They understand how restlessness and remorse arise; how, when they’ve already arisen, they’re given up; and how, once they’re given up, they don’t arise again in the future.

dn22:13.8.pli: Santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ vicikicchaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ vicikicchā’ti pajānāti, asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ vicikicchaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ vicikicchā’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannāya vicikicchāya uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannāya vicikicchāya pahānaṃ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnāya vicikicchāya āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
dn22:13.8.eng: When they have doubt in them, they understand: ‘I have doubt in me.’ When they don’t have doubt in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have doubt in me.’ They understand how doubt arises; how, when it’s already arisen, it’s given up; and how, once it’s given up, it doesn’t arise again in the future.

dn22:13.9.pli: Iti ajjhattaṃ vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati.
dn22:13.9.eng: And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

dn22:13.10.pli: Samudayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati.
dn22:13.10.eng: They meditate observing the principles as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to both originate and vanish.

dn22:13.11.pli: ‘Atthi dhammā’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya, anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
dn22:13.11.eng: Or mindfulness is established that principles exist, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

dn22:13.12.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu nīvaraṇesu.
dn22:13.12.eng: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five hindrances.

dn22:14.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu.
dn22:14.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five grasping aggregates.

dn22:14.2.pli: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu?
dn22:14.2.eng: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five grasping aggregates?

dn22:14.4.pli: ‘iti rūpaṃ, iti rūpassa samudayo, iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo;
dn22:14.4.eng: Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.
dn22:14.4.comm: “Form” (rūpa) is one’s own body and the external material world experienced through the senses. More subtly, it represents the “appearance” of physical phenomena, even when experienced solely in the mind as color, visions, etc.

dn22:14.5.pli: iti vedanā, iti vedanāya samudayo, iti vedanāya atthaṅgamo;
dn22:14.5.eng: Such is feeling, such is the origin of feeling, such is the ending of feeling.

dn22:14.6.pli: iti saññā, iti saññāya samudayo, iti saññāya atthaṅgamo;
dn22:14.6.eng: Such is perception, such is the origin of perception, such is the ending of perception.
dn22:14.6.comm: “Perception” (saññā) is the recognition or interpretation of experience in terms of meaningful wholes. We see, for example, “color” yet we perceive a “person”. In the Vinaya we find many examples where a person perceived things in one way, yet they turned out to be something else.

dn22:14.7.pli: iti saṅkhārā, iti saṅkhārānaṃ samudayo, iti saṅkhārānaṃ atthaṅgamo,
dn22:14.7.eng: Such are choices, such is the origin of choices, such is the ending of choices.
dn22:14.7.comm: In the five aggregates, saṅkhārā is a synonym for “volition” (cetanā). The traditions later used it as a catch-all category for everything that does not fit in the other aggregates. In the suttas, however, the purpose of the aggregates is not to classify everything that exists, but to contemplate aspects of experience that we tend to identify as a “self”.

dn22:14.8.pli: iti viññāṇaṃ, iti viññāṇassa samudayo, iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo’ti,
dn22:14.8.eng: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’

dn22:14.9.pli: iti ajjhattaṃ vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati.
dn22:14.9.eng: And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally …

dn22:14.10.pli: Samudayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati.

dn22:14.11.pli: ‘Atthi dhammā’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya, anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.

dn22:14.12.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu.
dn22:14.12.eng: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five grasping aggregates.

dn22:15.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati chasu ajjhattikabāhiresu āyatanesu.
dn22:15.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the six interior and exterior sense fields.

dn22:15.2.pli: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati chasu ajjhattikabāhiresu āyatanesu?
dn22:15.2.eng: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the six interior and exterior sense fields?

dn22:15.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhuñca pajānāti, rūpe ca pajānāti, yañca tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saṃyojanaṃ tañca pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa saṃyojanassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa saṃyojanassa pahānaṃ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa saṃyojanassa āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
dn22:15.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant understands the eye, sights, and the fetter that arises dependent on both of these. They understand how the fetter that has not arisen comes to arise; how the arisen fetter comes to be abandoned; and how the abandoned fetter comes to not rise again in the future.
dn22:15.3.comm: At SN 35.232:3.2 the “fetter that arises dependent on both” is identified as “desire and lust” (chandarāga).

dn22:15.4.pli: Sotañca pajānāti, sadde ca pajānāti, yañca tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saṃyojanaṃ tañca pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa saṃyojanassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa saṃyojanassa pahānaṃ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa saṃyojanassa āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
dn22:15.4.eng: They understand the ear, sounds, and the fetter …

dn22:15.5.pli: Ghānañca pajānāti, gandhe ca pajānāti, yañca tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saṃyojanaṃ tañca pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa saṃyojanassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa saṃyojanassa pahānaṃ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa saṃyojanassa āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
dn22:15.5.eng: They understand the nose, smells, and the fetter …

dn22:15.6.pli: Jivhañca pajānāti, rase ca pajānāti, yañca tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saṃyojanaṃ tañca pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa saṃyojanassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa saṃyojanassa pahānaṃ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa saṃyojanassa āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
dn22:15.6.eng: They understand the tongue, tastes, and the fetter …

dn22:15.7.pli: Kāyañca pajānāti, phoṭṭhabbe ca pajānāti, yañca tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saṃyojanaṃ tañca pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa saṃyojanassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa saṃyojanassa pahānaṃ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa saṃyojanassa āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
dn22:15.7.eng: They understand the body, touches, and the fetter …

dn22:15.8.pli: Manañca pajānāti, dhamme ca pajānāti, yañca tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saṃyojanaṃ tañca pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa saṃyojanassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa saṃyojanassa pahānaṃ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa saṃyojanassa āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti.
dn22:15.8.eng: They understand the mind, ideas, and the fetter that arises dependent on both of these. They understand how the fetter that has not arisen comes to arise; how the arisen fetter comes to be abandoned; and how the abandoned fetter comes to not rise again in the future.

dn22:15.9.pli: Iti ajjhattaṃ vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati.
dn22:15.9.eng: And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally …

dn22:15.10.pli: Samudayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati.

dn22:15.11.pli: ‘Atthi dhammā’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya, anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.

dn22:15.12.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati chasu ajjhattikabāhiresu āyatanesu.
dn22:15.12.eng: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the six interior and exterior sense fields.

dn22:16.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati sattasu bojjhaṅgesu.
dn22:16.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the seven awakening factors.
dn22:16.1.comm: These seven factors that lead to awakening (bojjhaṅgā, SN 46.5) are commonly presented in opposition to the five hindrances (eg. SN 46.2, SN 46.23, SN 46.55).

dn22:16.2.pli: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati sattasu bojjhaṅgesu?
dn22:16.2.eng: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the seven awakening factors?

dn22:16.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ satisambojjhaṅgaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ satisambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ satisambojjhaṅgaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ satisambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa satisambojjhaṅgassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa satisambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya pāripūrī hoti tañca pajānāti.
dn22:16.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant who has the awakening factor of mindfulness in them understands: ‘I have the awakening factor of mindfulness in me.’ When they don’t have the awakening factor of mindfulness in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have the awakening factor of mindfulness in me.’ They understand how the awakening factor of mindfulness that has not arisen comes to arise; and how the awakening factor of mindfulness that has arisen becomes fulfilled by development.
dn22:16.3.comm: “Mindfulness” includes the recollection of the teachings (SN 46.3:1.8) as well as mindfulness meditation.

dn22:16.4.pli: Santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya pāripūrī hoti tañca pajānāti.
dn22:16.4.eng: When they have the awakening factor of investigation of principles …
dn22:16.4.comm: Likewise, this includes the inquiry into dhammas as “teachings” as well as “phenomena” or “principles”.

dn22:16.5.pli: Santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ vīriyasambojjhaṅgaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ vīriyasambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ vīriyasambojjhaṅgaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ vīriyasambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa vīriyasambojjhaṅgassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa vīriyasambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya pāripūrī hoti tañca pajānāti.

dn22:16.6.pli: Santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ pītisambojjhaṅgaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ pītisambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ pītisambojjhaṅgaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ pītisambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa pītisambojjhaṅgassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa pītisambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya pāripūrī hoti tañca pajānāti.

dn22:16.7.pli: Santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ passaddhisambojjhaṅgaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ passaddhisambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ passaddhisambojjhaṅgaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ passaddhisambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa passaddhisambojjhaṅgassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa passaddhisambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya pāripūrī hoti tañca pajānāti.

dn22:16.8.pli: Santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ samādhisambojjhaṅgaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ samādhisambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ samādhisambojjhaṅgaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ samādhisambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa samādhisambojjhaṅgassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa samādhisambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya pāripūrī hoti tañca pajānāti.

dn22:16.9.pli: Santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa upekkhāsambojjhaṅgassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa upekkhāsambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya pāripūrī hoti tañca pajānāti.
dn22:16.9.eng: equanimity in them, they understand: ‘I have the awakening factor of equanimity in me.’ When they don’t have the awakening factor of equanimity in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have the awakening factor of equanimity in me.’ They understand how the awakening factor of equanimity that has not arisen comes to arise; and how the awakening factor of equanimity that has arisen becomes fulfilled by development.

dn22:16.10.pli: Iti ajjhattaṃ vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati.
dn22:16.10.eng: And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

dn22:16.11.pli: Samudayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati.
dn22:16.11.eng: They meditate observing the principles as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to both originate and vanish.

dn22:16.12.pli: ‘Atthi dhammā’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya, anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
dn22:16.12.eng: Or mindfulness is established that principles exist, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

dn22:16.13.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati sattasu bojjhaṅgesu.
dn22:16.13.eng: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the seven awakening factors.

dn22:17.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati catūsu ariyasaccesu.
dn22:17.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the four noble truths.
dn22:17.1.comm: Due to their development of the two wings of samatha and vipassanā meditation as described in this sutta, practised in the context of the teaching and training as a whole, the meditator realizes the four noble truths at the moment of stream-entry.

dn22:17.2.pli: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati catūsu ariyasaccesu?
dn22:17.2.eng: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the four noble truths?

dn22:17.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
dn22:17.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

dn22:17.4.eng: The first recitation section is finished.

dn22:18.1.eng: And what is the noble truth of suffering?
dn22:18.1.comm: The sutta now proceeds in analytical fashion, digging deeper into the details of the four noble truths. The fundamental definitions were taught in the Buddha’s first sermon (SN 56.11:4.1).

dn22:18.2.pli: Jātipi dukkhā, jarāpi dukkhā, maraṇampi dukkhaṃ, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsāpi dukkhā, appiyehi sampayogopi dukkho, piyehi vippayogopi dukkho, yampicchaṃ na labhati tampi dukkhaṃ, saṅkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā.
dn22:18.2.eng: Rebirth is suffering; old age is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are suffering; being coupled with the disliked is suffering; separation from the liked is suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering. In brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering.

dn22:18.4.pli: Yā tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ tamhi tamhi sattanikāye jāti sañjāti okkanti abhinibbatti khandhānaṃ pātubhāvo āyatanānaṃ paṭilābho,
dn22:18.4.eng: The rebirth, inception, conception, regeneration, manifestation of the sets of phenomena, and acquisition of the sense fields of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.
dn22:18.4.comm: As at DN 15:4.3, jāti is invariably defined as the rebirth of beings, not as simple arising. The same applies to old age and death.

dn22:18.7.pli: Yā tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ tamhi tamhi sattanikāye jarā jīraṇatā khaṇḍiccaṃ pāliccaṃ valittacatā āyuno saṃhāni indriyānaṃ paripāko,
dn22:18.7.eng: The old age, decrepitude, broken teeth, grey hair, wrinkly skin, diminished vitality, and failing faculties of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.

dn22:18.10.pli: Yaṃ tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ tamhā tamhā sattanikāyā cuti cavanatā bhedo antaradhānaṃ maccu maraṇaṃ kālakiriyā khandhānaṃ bhedo kaḷevarassa nikkhepo jīvitindriyassupacchedo,
dn22:18.10.eng: The passing away, passing on, disintegration, demise, mortality, death, decease, breaking up of the aggregates, laying to rest of the corpse, and cutting off of the life faculty of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.

dn22:18.13.pli: Yo kho, bhikkhave, aññataraññatarena byasanena samannāgatassa aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa soko socanā socitattaṃ antosoko antoparisoko,
dn22:18.13.eng: The sorrow, sorrowing, state of sorrow, inner sorrow, inner deep sorrow in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering.
dn22:18.13.comm: In this and following definitions we mainly find mere verbal variations of the basic term.

dn22:18.16.pli: Yo kho, bhikkhave, aññataraññatarena byasanena samannāgatassa aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa ādevo paridevo ādevanā paridevanā ādevitattaṃ paridevitattaṃ,
dn22:18.16.eng: The wail, lament, wailing, lamenting, state of wailing and lamentation in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering.

dn22:18.19.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, kāyikaṃ dukkhaṃ kāyikaṃ asātaṃ kāyasamphassajaṃ dukkhaṃ asātaṃ vedayitaṃ,
dn22:18.19.eng: Physical pain, physical unpleasantness, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from physical contact.
dn22:18.19.comm: Dukkha (“pain”, “suffering”) is here restricted to physical pain. Elsewhere it may be any kind of painful feeling, while in the four noble truths it is suffering of any sort, including subtle forms of existential suffering.

dn22:18.21.comm: Domanassa normally means “sadness”, but sometimes it contrasts with desire, in which case it is a form of aversion.

dn22:18.22.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, cetasikaṃ dukkhaṃ cetasikaṃ asātaṃ manosamphassajaṃ dukkhaṃ asātaṃ vedayitaṃ,
dn22:18.22.eng: Mental pain, mental displeasure, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from mental contact.

dn22:18.25.pli: Yo kho, bhikkhave, aññataraññatarena byasanena samannāgatassa aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa āyāso upāyāso āyāsitattaṃ upāyāsitattaṃ,
dn22:18.25.eng: The stress, distress, state of stress and distress in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering.

dn22:18.27.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, appiyehi sampayogo dukkho?
dn22:18.27.eng: And what is meant by ‘being coupled with the disliked is suffering’?

dn22:18.28.pli: Idha yassa te honti aniṭṭhā akantā amanāpā rūpā saddā gandhā rasā phoṭṭhabbā dhammā, ye vā panassa te honti anatthakāmā ahitakāmā aphāsukakāmā ayogakkhemakāmā, yā tehi saddhiṃ saṅgati samāgamo samodhānaṃ missībhāvo,
dn22:18.28.eng: There are sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas, which are unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable. And there are those who want to harm, injure, disturb, and threaten you. The coming together with these, the joining, inclusion, mixing with them:

dn22:18.29.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, appiyehi sampayogo dukkho.
dn22:18.29.eng: this is what is meant by ‘being coupled with the disliked is suffering’.

dn22:18.30.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, piyehi vippayogo dukkho?
dn22:18.30.eng: And what is meant by ‘separation from the liked is suffering’?

dn22:18.31.pli: Idha yassa te honti iṭṭhā kantā manāpā rūpā saddā gandhā rasā phoṭṭhabbā dhammā, ye vā panassa te honti atthakāmā hitakāmā phāsukakāmā yogakkhemakāmā mātā vā pitā vā bhātā vā bhaginī vā mittā vā amaccā vā ñātisālohitā vā, yā tehi saddhiṃ asaṅgati asamāgamo asamodhānaṃ amissībhāvo,
dn22:18.31.eng: There are sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas, which are likable, desirable, and agreeable. And there are those who want to help, benefit, comfort, and protect you: mother and father, brother and sister, friends and colleagues, relatives and kin. The division from these, the disconnection, segregation, and parting from them:
dn22:18.31.comm: Piya often refers to those who are dear and beloved, but as shown here it can also mean simply anything that is liked.

dn22:18.32.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, piyehi vippayogo dukkho.
dn22:18.32.eng: this is what is meant by ‘separation from the liked is suffering’.

dn22:18.33.pli: Katamañca, bhikkhave, yampicchaṃ na labhati tampi dukkhaṃ?
dn22:18.33.eng: And what is meant by ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering’?

dn22:18.34.pli: Jātidhammānaṃ, bhikkhave, sattānaṃ evaṃ icchā uppajjati:
dn22:18.34.eng: In sentient beings who are liable to be reborn, such a wish arises:

dn22:18.35.pli: ‘aho vata mayaṃ na jātidhammā assāma, na ca vata no jāti āgaccheyyā’ti.
dn22:18.35.eng: ‘Oh, if only we were not liable to be reborn! If only rebirth would not come to us!’
dn22:18.35.comm: This is an example of “painful feeling not of the flesh”. The Buddha is here denying the efficacy of prayer, invocation, or magic spells.

dn22:18.36.eng: But you can’t get that by wishing.

dn22:18.37.pli: idampi yampicchaṃ na labhati tampi dukkhaṃ.
dn22:18.37.eng: This is what is meant by ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering.’

dn22:18.38.pli: Jarādhammānaṃ, bhikkhave, sattānaṃ evaṃ icchā uppajjati:
dn22:18.38.eng: In sentient beings who are liable to grow old …

dn22:18.39.pli: ‘aho vata mayaṃ na jarādhammā assāma, na ca vata no jarā āgaccheyyā’ti.

dn22:18.40.pli: Na kho panetaṃ icchāya pattabbaṃ, idampi yampicchaṃ na labhati tampi dukkhaṃ.

dn22:18.41.pli: Byādhidhammānaṃ, bhikkhave, sattānaṃ evaṃ icchā uppajjati ‘aho vata mayaṃ na byādhidhammā assāma, na ca vata no byādhi āgaccheyyā’ti.

dn22:18.42.pli: Na kho panetaṃ icchāya pattabbaṃ, idampi yampicchaṃ na labhati tampi dukkhaṃ.

dn22:18.43.pli: Maraṇadhammānaṃ, bhikkhave, sattānaṃ evaṃ icchā uppajjati ‘aho vata mayaṃ na maraṇadhammā assāma, na ca vata no maraṇaṃ āgaccheyyā’ti.

dn22:18.44.pli: Na kho panetaṃ icchāya pattabbaṃ, idampi yampicchaṃ na labhati tampi dukkhaṃ.

dn22:18.45.pli: Sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammānaṃ, bhikkhave, sattānaṃ evaṃ icchā uppajjati ‘aho vata mayaṃ na sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā assāma, na ca vata no sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsaā āgaccheyyun’ti.
dn22:18.45.eng: experience sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress, such a wish arises: ‘Oh, if only we were not liable to experience sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress! If only sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress would not come to us!’

dn22:18.46.eng: But you can’t get that by wishing.

dn22:18.47.pli: idampi yampicchaṃ na labhati tampi dukkhaṃ.
dn22:18.47.eng: This is what is meant by ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering.’

dn22:18.48.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, saṅkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā?
dn22:18.48.eng: And what is meant by ‘in brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering’?

dn22:18.49.eng: They are the grasping aggregates that consist of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

dn22:18.50.pli: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, saṅkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā.
dn22:18.50.eng: This is what is meant by ‘in brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering’.

dn22:18.51.eng: This is called the noble truth of suffering.

dn22:19.1.eng: And what is the noble truth of the origin of suffering?

dn22:19.2.pli: Yāyaṃ taṇhā ponobbhavikā nandīrāgasahagatā tatratatrābhinandinī, seyyathidaṃ—
dn22:19.2.eng: It’s the craving that leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure wherever it lands. That is,

dn22:19.3.eng: craving for sensual pleasures, craving for existence, and craving for nonexistence.

dn22:19.4.pli: Sā kho panesā, bhikkhave, taṇhā kattha uppajjamānā uppajjati, kattha nivisamānā nivisati?
dn22:19.4.eng: But where does that craving arise and where does it settle?

dn22:19.5.pli: Yaṃ loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
dn22:19.5.eng: Whatever in the world seems nice and pleasant, it is there that craving arises and settles.

dn22:19.6.eng: And what in the world seems nice and pleasant?

dn22:19.7.pli: Cakkhu loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
dn22:19.7.eng: The eye in the world seems nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving arises and settles.
dn22:19.7.comm: The following list of properties that relate to the senses gradually moves from the more basic to the more sophisticated.

dn22:19.12.pli: mano loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
dn22:19.12.eng: mind in the world seems nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving arises and settles.

dn22:19.18.pli: dhammā loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
dn22:19.18.eng: ideas in the world seem nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving arises and settles.

dn22:19.19.comm: “Eye consciousness” is aware only of “light”; it sees colors but does not interpret them.

dn22:19.24.pli: manoviññāṇaṃ loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
dn22:19.24.eng: mind consciousness in the world seems nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving arises and settles.

dn22:19.25.comm: “Contact” or “stimulus” happens when the sense base, the sense object, and the sense consciousness all occur together.

dn22:19.30.pli: manosamphasso loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
dn22:19.30.eng: mind contact in the world seems nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving arises and settles.

dn22:19.36.pli: manosamphassajā vedanā loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
dn22:19.36.eng: feeling born of mind contact in the world seems nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving arises and settles.

dn22:19.37.comm: “Perception” interprets the “light” that is seen, organizing it in meaningful wholes. For example, the eye sees the color white, while perception recognizes that it is “white”, and further, that that white color is in fact a “wall”.

dn22:19.42.pli: dhammasaññā loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
dn22:19.42.eng: perception of ideas in the world seems nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving arises and settles.

dn22:19.43.comm: To continue the example, once the light has been interpreted by perception as a “wall”, we then make the choice to walk around it rather than through it. Choices therefore depend on perceptions.

dn22:19.48.pli: dhammasañcetanā loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
dn22:19.48.eng: intention regarding ideas in the world seems nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving arises and settles.

dn22:19.54.pli: dhammataṇhā loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
dn22:19.54.eng: craving for ideas in the world seems nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving arises and settles.

dn22:19.60.pli: dhammavitakko loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
dn22:19.60.eng: thoughts about ideas in the world seem nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving arises and settles.

dn22:19.61.comm: “Consideration” is vicāra, a more sustained exercize of thought.

dn22:19.66.pli: dhammavicāro loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
dn22:19.66.eng: considerations regarding ideas in the world seem nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving arises and settles.

dn22:19.67.eng: This is called the noble truth of the origin of suffering.

dn22:20.1.eng: And what is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering?

dn22:20.2.pli: Yo tassāyeva taṇhāya asesavirāganirodho cāgo paṭinissaggo mutti anālayo.
dn22:20.2.eng: It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not clinging to it.

dn22:20.3.pli: Sā kho panesā, bhikkhave, taṇhā kattha pahīyamānā pahīyati, kattha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati?

dn22:20.4.pli: Yaṃ loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati.
dn22:20.4.eng: Whatever in the world seems nice and pleasant, it is there that craving is given up and ceases.

dn22:20.5.eng: And what in the world seems nice and pleasant?

dn22:20.6.pli: Cakkhu loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati.
dn22:20.6.eng: The eye in the world seems nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving is given up and ceases. …

dn22:20.11.pli: mano loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati.

dn22:20.17.pli: dhammā loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati.

dn22:20.23.pli: manoviññāṇaṃ loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati.

dn22:20.29.pli: manosamphasso loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati.

dn22:20.35.pli: manosamphassajā vedanā loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati.

dn22:20.41.pli: dhammasaññā loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati.

dn22:20.47.pli: dhammasañcetanā loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati.

dn22:20.53.pli: dhammataṇhā loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati.

dn22:20.59.pli: dhammavitakko loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati.

dn22:20.65.pli: dhammavicāro loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati.
dn22:20.65.eng: Considerations regarding ideas in the world seem nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving is given up and ceases.

dn22:20.66.eng: This is called the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.

dn22:21.1.eng: And what is the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering?

dn22:21.2.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

dn22:21.3.pli: sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappo sammāvācā sammākammanto sammāājīvo sammāvāyāmo sammāsati sammāsamādhi.
dn22:21.3.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
dn22:21.3.comm: Mindfulness is not a path in and of itself, but rather is the seventh factor of the eightfold path.

dn22:21.5.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, dukkhe ñāṇaṃ, dukkhasamudaye ñāṇaṃ, dukkhanirodhe ñāṇaṃ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇaṃ.
dn22:21.5.eng: Knowing about suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
dn22:21.5.comm: The fourth noble truth is the path, while the first path factor is the noble truths. These two teachings are different perspectives on the same dhamma.

dn22:21.8.eng: Thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.
dn22:21.8.comm: Saṅkappa is normally a synonym of vitakka in the suttas, hence the rendering “right thought”. It is, however, not just verbalized thought, but the direction in which one applies the mind. This factor is the emotional counterpart of right view, ensuring that the path is motivated by love and compassion.

dn22:21.11.pli: Musāvādā veramaṇī pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇī pharusāya vācāya veramaṇī samphappalāpā veramaṇī.
dn22:21.11.eng: The refraining from lying, divisive speech, harsh speech, and talking nonsense.

dn22:21.14.pli: Pāṇātipātā veramaṇī adinnādānā veramaṇī kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇī.
dn22:21.14.eng: Refraining from killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct.
dn22:21.14.comm: The first three of the five precepts. “Sexual misconduct” is the betrayal of trust in a sexual relationship.

dn22:21.17.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako micchāājīvaṃ pahāya sammāājīvena jīvitaṃ kappeti.
dn22:21.17.eng: It’s when a noble disciple gives up wrong livelihood and earns a living by right livelihood.
dn22:21.17.comm: Defined for a monastic in the long section on ethics in the Sāmaññaphalasutta (DN 2:56.1) and for a lay person as trade in weapons, living creatures, meat, intoxicants, and poisons (AN 5.177:1.3).

dn22:21.20.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anuppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ anuppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati;
dn22:21.20.eng: It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise.

dn22:21.21.pli: uppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati;
dn22:21.21.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen are given up.

dn22:21.22.pli: anuppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ uppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati;
dn22:21.22.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities arise.

dn22:21.23.pli: uppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
dn22:21.23.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development.

dn22:21.26.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
dn22:21.26.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

dn22:21.27.pli: vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
dn22:21.27.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

dn22:21.28.pli: citte cittānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
dn22:21.28.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

dn22:21.29.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
dn22:21.29.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

dn22:21.32.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn22:21.32.eng: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

dn22:21.33.pli: Vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn22:21.33.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

dn22:21.34.pli: Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati, sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn22:21.34.eng: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

dn22:21.35.pli: Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn22:21.35.eng: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

dn22:21.37.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ.
dn22:21.37.eng: This is called the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

dn22:21.38.pli: Iti ajjhattaṃ vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati.
dn22:21.38.eng: And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

dn22:21.39.pli: Samudayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati.
dn22:21.39.eng: They meditate observing the principles as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to both originate and vanish.

dn22:21.40.pli: ‘Atthi dhammā’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
dn22:21.40.eng: Or mindfulness is established that principles exist, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

dn22:21.41.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati catūsu ariyasaccesu.
dn22:21.41.eng: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the four noble truths.

dn22:22.1.pli: Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne evaṃ bhāveyya sattavassāni, tassa dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ
dn22:22.1.eng: Anyone who develops these four kinds of mindfulness meditation in this way for seven years can expect one of two results:
dn22:22.1.comm: The emphasis is on “develop in this way” (evaṁ bhāveyya), that is, with the full practice including deep absorption as the culmination of the path as a whole.

dn22:22.2.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā; sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā.
dn22:22.2.eng: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.

dn22:22.3.comm: A similar promise of results in at most seven years is found at DN 25:22.9, MN 10:46.3, and MN 85:59.3; and at most ten years at AN 10.46:7.3.

dn22:22.4.pli: Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne evaṃ bhāveyya cha vassāni …pe…
dn22:22.4.eng: anyone who develops these four kinds of mindfulness meditation in this way for six years …

dn22:22.11.pli: Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne evaṃ bhāveyya sattamāsāni, tassa dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ

dn22:22.12.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā; sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā.

dn22:22.14.pli: Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne evaṃ bhāveyya cha māsāni …pe…

dn22:22.22.pli: Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne evaṃ bhāveyya sattāhaṃ, tassa dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ
dn22:22.22.eng: anyone who develops these four kinds of mindfulness meditation in this way for seven days can expect one of two results:

dn22:22.23.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā; sati vā upādisese anāgāmitāti.
dn22:22.23.eng: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.

dn22:22.24.pli: Ekāyano ayaṃ, bhikkhave, maggo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya yadidaṃ cattāro satipaṭṭhānāti.
dn22:22.24.eng: ‘The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.’

dn22:22.25.pli: Iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttan”ti.
dn22:22.25.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.”

dn22:22.26.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

dn22:22.27.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
dn22:22.27.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
